statement.p: For each problem, select the best response.

(a) For a biology project, you measure the weight in grams and the tail length in millimeters of a group of mice. The correlation is r = 0.9. If you had measured tail length in centimeters instead of millimeters, what would be the correlation? (There are 10 millimeters in a centimeter.)
(b) A study found a correlation of r = -0.61 between the gender of a worker and his or her income. You may correctly conclude

li.p: women earn less than men on average.
women earn more than men on average.
an arithmetic mistake was made. Correlation must be positive.
this is incorrect because r makes no sense here.

A fair 6-sided die is rolled 5 times and the resulting sequence of 5 numbers is recorded.
How many different sequences are possible?
How many different sequences consist entirely of even numbers?
How many different sequences are possible if the first, third, and fourth numbers must be the same?
Find how many positive integers with exactly four decimal digits, that is, positive integers between 1000 and 9999 inclusive, have the following properties:
(a) are divisible by 7.
(b) are divisible by 5 or by 7 (inclusive or).
(c) have distinct digits.
(d) are divisible by 5 and by 7.
In how many ways can 4 different novels, 2 different mathematics books, and 1 biology book be arranged on a bookshelf if
(a) the books can be arranged in any order?
Answer:
(b) the mathematics books must be together and the novels must be together?
Answer:
(c) the mathematics books must be together but the other books can be arranged in any order?
Answer:
How many anagrams can be created from the word 'masslessness' if the new words do not need to be meaningful?
A standard deck of cards consists of four suits (clubs, diamonds, hearts, and spades), with each suit containing 13 cards (ace, two through ten, jack, queen, and king) for a total of 52 cards in all.
How many 7-card hands will consist of exactly 3 hearts and 2 clubs?

A school dance committee is to consist of 2 freshmen, 3 sophomores, 4 juniors, and 5 seniors. If 7 freshmen, 7 sophomores, 9 juniors, and 8 seniors are eligible to be on the committee, in how many ways can the committee be chosen?
Your answer is :

static.solution: There are {7 \choose 2} ways to choose 2 freshmen for the committee, {7 \choose 3} ways to choose 3 sophomores for the committee, {9 \choose 4} ways to choose 4 juniors for the committee, and {8 \choose 5} ways to choose 5 seniors for the committee. So by the generalized basic principle of counting, there are a total of {7 \choose 2} \cdot {7 \choose 3} \cdot {9 \choose 4} \cdot {8 \choose 5} = \frac{7 !}{2!5 !} \cdot \frac{7 !}{3! 4 !} \cdot \frac{9 !}{4! 5 !} \cdot \frac{8 !}{5! 3 !} = 5186160 different possible committees.

hint.p: Odds in favor of an event = number of favorable outcomes / number of unfavorable outcomes.
Odds against an event = number of unfavorable outcomes / number of favorable outcomes.

Answer:

A biomedical research company produces 44 \% of its insulin at a plant in Kansas City, and the remainder is produced at a plant in Jefferson City. Quality control has shown that 0.9 \% of the insulin produced at the plant in Kansas City is defective, while 1.3 \% of the insulin produced at the plant in Jefferson City is defective. What is the probability that a randomly chosen unit of insulin came from the plant in Jefferson City given that it is defective?
(Hint: Draw a tree diagram first)

Suppose that one individual is selected at random and it is discovered that the individual smokes. Use the probabilities in the following table to calculate the probability that the individual is a college graduate.

Find the expected value for the random variable:
Prizes and the chances of winning in a sweepstakes are given in the table below.
(a) Find the expected value (in dollars) of the amount won by one entry.
(b) Find the expected value (in dollars) if the cost of entering this sweepstakes is the cost of a postage stamp (34 cents)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) Let W be the amount of money (in dollars) won by an entry. Then \begin{aligned} E[W] = \amp 25000000\cdot P(W = 25000000) + 450000 \cdot P(W = 450000) + 50000 \cdot P(W = 50000)\\ \amp + \, 15000 \cdot P(W = 15000) +800 \cdot P( W = 800) + 45 \cdot P( W = 45)\\ \amp = \frac{25000000}{200000000} + \frac{450000}{200000000} + \frac{50000}{80000000} + \frac{15000}{1000000} + \frac{800}{900000} + \frac{45}{7000} \\ \amp = 0.15019246031746 \end{aligned} So the expected value of the amount won by one entry in the sweepstakes is about 15 cents.
(b) Let X be the net earnings from one entry into the sweepstakes. Then X = W - 0.34, so E[X] = E[W- 0.34] = E[W] - 0.34 = -0.18980753968254. Hence, taking into account the cost of postage, there is an expected loss of about 19 cents from one entry into the sweepstakes.

Determine the probability that she fails to make a sale on the first five interviews:
Determine the probability that she makes her first sale on the fourth interview:
Determine the probability that the second sale is made on the sixth interview:

solution.p: Using negative binomial with r=2, P(X = 6) = f(6) = 5 (1-p)^4 \cdot p^2 = 5 \cdot 0.89^4 \cdot 0.11^2 \approx 0.04209

Customers arrive at a grocery store at an average of 2 per minute. Assume that the number of arrivals in a minute follows the Poisson distribution. Provide answers to the following to 3 decimal places.
What is the probability that exactly two customers arrive in a minute?
Find the probability that more than three customers arrive in a two-minute period.
What is the probability that at least seven customers arrive in three minutes, given that exactly two arrive in the first minute?

solution.p: Let X be the number of customers arriving in a one-minute interval. Then X \sim Po(2), and
If Y denotes the number of customers arriving in a two-minute interval, then Y \sim Po(2 \times 2), and \Pr(Y > 3) = 1 - \Pr(Y \leq 3) = 0.000. Via R:

For i = 1, 2, 3, let X_i be the number of customers arriving in minute i. These variables are independent, since counts in a Poisson process over non-overlapping intervals are independent; moreover X \sim Po(2). Hence

p.m: \begin{align*} \Pr(X_1 + X_2 + X_3 \geq 7 | X_1 = 2) \amp = \frac{\Pr(X_1 + X_2 + X_3 \geq 7, X_1 = 2)}{\Pr(X_1 = 2)} \\ \amp = \frac{\Pr(X_2 + X_3 \geq 5) \Pr(X_1 = 2)}{\Pr(X_1 = 2)} \\ \amp = \Pr(X_2 + X_3 \geq 5) \\ \amp = \Pr(Y \geq 5) \end{align*}

solution.p: where Y \sim Po(4) as in part b. The result is 0.000. Via R:

statement.p: Suppose that the time (in hours) required to repair a machine is an exponentially distributed random variable with parameter \lambda = 0.6. What is
(a) the probability that a repair takes less than 8 hours?
(b) the conditional probability that a repair takes at least 6 hours, given that it takes more than 3 hours?

It can be presumed that the life span in years of a certain brand of lightbulbs follows the Poisson process assumptions. Suppose that the mean life span till failure is known to be 0.7 years. A tester makes random observations of the life times of this particular brand of lightbulbs and records them one by one as either a success if the life time exceeds 1 year, or as a failure otherwise.
Determine the probability that a randomly tested bulb lasts more than 1 year:
Determine probability that the first success occurs in the fifth observation:
Determine the probability that the second success occurs in the 8th observation given that the first success occurred in the 3rd observation:
Determine the probability that the first success occurs in an odd-numbered observation:

hint.p: Use the exponential distribution to get the first answer. Use the geometric to get the remainder.

solution.p: Using the exponential distribution, p = P(X \gt 1) = 1 - F(1) = 1 - (1-e^{-\frac{1}{0.7}}) \approx 0.2397.

Now, use the geometric distribution with p = 0.2397... P(X = 5) = f(5) = (1-0.2397)^4 \cdot 0.2397 \approx 0.0801. P(\text{2nd success on 8} | \text{1st success on 3}) = P(X = 5) \approx 0.0801 P(\text{1st success on an odd trial}) & = f(1) + f(3) + f(5) + ... & = p + (1-p)^2 \cdot p + (1-p)^4 \cdot p + (1-p)^6 \cdot p + ... & = p \sum_{x=0}^{\infty} \left ( (1-p)^2 \right)^k & = p \frac{1}{1-(1-p)^2} \approx 0.5681

hint.p: Use the exponential distribution to get the first answer. Use the geometric to get the remainder.

solution.p: Now, use the geometric distribution with p = 0.2397\text{...}

p.me: P(\text{2nd success on 8} | \text{1st success on 3}) = P(X = 5) \approx 0.0801

A noted psychic was tested for ESP. The psychic was presented with 220 cards face down and was asked to determine if the card was one of 5 symbols: a star, cross, circle, square, or three wavy lines. To see if there is evidence that the psychic is doing better than just guessing, we test

(b) What is the P-value of the test?
